tasks.task: Planting peas and canola with Clearfield technology for research on root rot inhibition.
subtasks: Choose Clearfield technology for peas (13th of June)
Use Raptor or Beyond for weed control (decision not made)
Plant peas with canola in same drill using pre-plant herbicide (grass herbicide only, no fertilizer)

tasks.task: Managing hail damage and desiccating crops.
subtasks: Deal with 90 mph hailstorm on south end of field (13th June)
Apply desiccant (quarter roundup) when peas and canola are crispy (late July)
Adjust header settings for residue distribution (draper header used for Canola)
Determine bushel weights (7-8 bushels an acre) and mix composition (2/3 peas, 1/3 canola)
Store mixed crops without cleaning due to time constraints but with successful moisture management
Avoid mold issues due to proper residue distribution (quarter roundup used)

tasks.task: Conducting trials with different legumes and canola combinations.
subtasks: Try chickpeas and flax with same drill (150 lbs chickpea seed resulted in too much, reduced to 120 lbs)
Test yellow peas and canola for maturity timing and shattering (Tennis ball-sized hail storm affected)
Switch to maple peas and canola population trials (various rates and AMS)

tasks.task: Dealing with hail and weed issues in subsequent years.
subtasks: Hail damage in 2019 and using stripper head (shattered too much canola, shifted to draper head)
Address weed pressure with VALOR (fall application)
Scout for diseases (Phantomiasis found in lentil and flax trial)
Rotate crops with mustard and oats to manage root rot in historically infected field
Evaluate success of mustard in reducing root rot (mixed results)
Consider long-term impact of continuous legume cropping (disease buildup in 8 years)
Compare costs (chemicals, seed) and income (peas, mustard) of different intercrops
Weigh benefits against traditional cropping systems (diversification, lower input costs, higher yields)
Consider potential for crop insurance and its cost
Experiment with stripper heads for uniform harvest (yellow pea and flax, large-scale difficulty)
Handle shatter issues with peas and mustards (use draper headers for best results)
Manage irregular harvest rates (e.g., some areas performing better than others)

Planting peas and canola with Clearfield technology for root rot inhibition. So that must involve choosing the Clearfield tech (SUBTASK 1), deciding on weed control options (Raptor or Beyond; they didn't use Raptor, though), and planting the mixture in the same drill with pre-plant herbicide (SUBTASK 3).

90 mph winds, tennis ball-sized hail, 13th June). Their response was to use a desiccant (quarter roundup) to dry the crops (SUBTASK 2), and they had to adjust header settings because they were using a draper header due to residue issues (SUBTASK 3 – avoiding shattering by using appropriate headers).

For storage, they didn't clean the mixed crops immediately (due to time constraints) but were pleased with moisture management (SUBTASK 1 - kept peas and canola separate with quarter roundup, leading to no mold issues even after a year and a half).

Next, they conducted trials with different legumes and canola. That's MAINTASK 3. They started with chickpeas and flax (SUBTASK 1 – found too much shatter, adjusted rates). Then tried yellow peas and canola (hail damaged, difficult to harvest). In 2019, they switched to maple peas and canola, doing different population trials (three rates). Each year, they varied the seed rates based on results or issues (e.g., 120 lbs maple, 110 lbs, 100 lbs). They also tried different components like lentils and mustard in later years, encountering issues with diseases (Phantomiasis in lentil trial).

tasks.task: Dealing with hail and specific crop issues) could cover their responses to hail damage (like using desiccants in 2018), switching to different drills (from stripper to draper), and dealing with shortages (i.e., only having half the mustard rate in one trial but found it thinned). In 2020, they used mustard and maple peas with an oat field, which had its own set of challenges like volunteer oats requiring two grass herbicide applications. They noticed flea beetle damage but the peas helped mitigate it.

Rotational challenges and disease management, they found that continuous legume cropping led to root rot issues (8 years later), so adjusting rotations became necessary (in planted a strip of fall Valor, which thinned the mustard). They also considered the long-term effect of intercropping brassicas (like mustard) on diseases, but found it wasn't a complete cure.
subtasks: Economic considerations (MAINTASK 6) came into play when they broke down costs versus yields. For example, the variable cost analysis (SUBTASK 1) showed that while intercropping (like mustard and maple peas) might have lower net income, the profit margins compared to single crops could still be favorable (by 300 net instead of 189 after variable costs). They also considered the advantage of not scaring over the land (SUBTASK 2) and possibly higher combined yields (SUBTASK 3). However, they accept that it's not viable for all crops (e.g., flax had insufficient yields).

Lastly, harvesting drill-seeded mixtures (MAINTASK 7) was a challenge. They found that some crops, like yellow peas and mustard, required careful handling (SUBTASK 1 - using variable headers), while others, like lentils and flax, were messier (SUBTASK 2 - poor shatter control even with combined efforts). But they managed the challenges by adjusting equipment settings and cleaning methods (SUBTASK 3 - using neighboring mill for cleaning).

tasks.task: Planting peas and canola with Clearfield technology for root rot inhibition**
subtasks: ** Choose Clearfield technology for peas (13th of June).
** Consider using Raptor or Beyond for weed control (decided against Raptor).
** Plant peas with canola in the same drill using pre-plant herbicide (grass herbicide only, no fertilizer).

tasks.task: Managing hail damage and desiccating crops**
subtasks: ** Deal with 90 mph hailstorm, 90% wind speed, and tennis ball-sized hail (13th June) causing damage.
** Apply desiccant (quarter roundup) to dry the crops when crispy (late July).
** Adjust header settings for proper residue distribution (used a draper header).
** Determine bushel weights (7-8 per acre) and mix composition (2/3 peas, 1/3 canola).
** Store mixed crops without cleaning due to time constraints, avoiding mold issues.
** Use quarter roundup effectively to prevent moisture issues and mold (stored successfully for over a year).

tasks.task: Conducting trials with different legumes and canola combinations**
subtasks: ** Try chickpeas and flax in the same drill (too much shatter, reduced chickpea rate).
** Test yellow peas and canola maturity timing and shattering (affected by hail).
** Switch to maple peas and canola population trials (various rates and AMS).

tasks.task: Dealing with hail and weed issues in subsequent years**
subtasks: ** Hail damage in 2019; use stripper head (shattering too much, switched to draper head).
** Address weed pressure using fall application of VALOR.
** Scout for diseases like Phantomiasis (found in lentil and flax trials).
** Rotate crops (mustard and oats) to manage root rot (8-year history found disease buildup).
** Evaluate mustard’s effect on root rot (partial success).
** Consider long-term impacts of continuous legume cropping.
** Compare costs (chemicals, seed) and income (peas, mustard) of different intercrops.
** Weigh benefits of intercropping against traditional systems (diversification, lower input costs, higher yields).
** Consider potential crop insurance and its associated costs.
** Experiment with stripper heads for consistent harvest (difficult with yellow peas and mustards).
** Handle shatter issues (peas and mustards required careful handling).
** Use neighboring mills for cleaning and manage residue distribution.
